Él piensa que lo que hace diferente su tienda de es el buen servicio y sus precios. También comenta que se han abierto ya varias tiendas en su colonia, pero no han funcionado; la suya se mantiene ya que ha sabido administrase y tener paciencia, lo que más le gusta de su negocio es que todos los días está en contacto con las personas y ha hecho buenas amistades. Un crédito de VisionFund y Kiva le ayudara a comprar frijol, aceite, refrescos, sopa, arroz, dulces, galletas, productos enlatados, frituras y jugos para resurtir su negocio. 

Él espera que con esta inversión su negocio tenga más variedad de productos para ganar más clientes y aumentar sus ganancias. 

Los demás integrantes del grupo son:
Araceli venta de antojitos mexicanos 
Braulia venta de ropa 
Adela venta de calzado y lencería 
Luis Ricardo farmacia 
Estela tejido 
Rosa Isela venta de ropa 
Mónica venta de comida 
Selene club de nutrición
texts.en:
Alejo is one of the members of the 1Ero de Mayo [1st of May] group. He has been working in business for 7 years. He says he has always lived in the same district  and this is where he decided to open a grocery shop, with the intention of providing a service to his neighbours and earning his own money. He says he began by just selling soft drinks and sweets and gradually the shop has grown and currently is a grocery store. He thinks what makes his shop different is the good service and his prices. He also says that various shops have opened up in the district but they haven't worked out.  His has kept going because he knows how to run the business and have patience. What he likes most about his business is that every day he has contact with people and he has made good friendships.

A loan from VisionFund and Kiva will help him to buy beans, oil, drinks, soup, rice, sweets, cookies, canned products, chips and juices to stock his business. He hopes that with this investment his business will have a better variety of products to attract more customers and increase his profits. 

The other members of the group are:

Araceli: sells "antojitos" [Mexican snacks] 
Braulia: sells clothing
Adela: sells footwear and lingerie
Luis Ricardo: pharmacy
Estela: knitwear
Rosa Isela: sells clothing 
Mónica: sells food
Selene: nutrition club

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, oil, canned products, cookies, sweets, chips, sodas, juices, soup, soap, and toilet paper

loans.name: Jumwa

texts.en:
Jumwa is a married woman who has five school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Jumwa has operated a fish-selling business for the last three years, selling at the market and to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 15,000, Jumwa wants to purchase fish, cooking oil and firewood for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to acquire financial services for her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish, cooking oil and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Sayyad

texts.en:
Sayyad has been selling raw milk and farming products such as corn, cucumbers and eggplants at the local bazaar for 22 years. He is 49 and married with two children. His family lives with Sayyad's parents, sister and brother who are helping him in his business. 

The reason he has applied to VFAC is due to his wife's health problems. From time to time, she has to receive a treatment and therefore, Sayyaad needs money to pay for this. The sum he has applied for is 600 AZN.

loans.use: To cover the treatment expenses for his wife.

loans.name: Helberth

texts.es: Helberth, tiene la edad  de 51 años, está soltero, vive solo. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes orgánicos, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra en trabajos en conservación de suelos y de asistencia para el café que se encuentra con cosecha y el que sembró el año pasado, además de comprar algunas plantas de almácigo de la variedad inverníz para hacer resiembras esto con el objetivo de aumentar la densidad de plantas por área, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que a  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Él no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja
texts.en:
Helberth, 51, is single and lives alone.  He plans to use his loan to buy organic fertilizers, fungicides and hire workers to care for the soil and help with the current coffee harvest from the crop he planted last year.  He will also buy winter variety copperwood plants to replant to increase plant density in the area.  This way he will use the good soil fertility and weather conditions to enhance coffee cultivation.  These crop improvements will give him a profit and improve his family's living conditions.  Another of his goals is to invest a little more in the crop area.

This is his first loan through FUDECOSUR.  He has never had a state bank loan but FUDECOSUR is giving him better terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: with his coffee crop.

loans.name: Periquitas (Flat) Group

texts.es:
Las Periquitas (Flat) es el nombre de un grupo integrado por 4 personas, cada una de ellas desarrolla una actividad económica con el objetivo de brindar  una mejor calidad de vida a sus familias. El grupo está ubicado en una pequeña comunidad rodeada por sembradíos de caña de azúcar y la principal actividad económica es la siembra y cultivo de caña de azúcar.

Paula tiene un negocio de venta de zapatos y ropa interior a través de pedidos por catálogo. Paula realiza sus  ventas  casa por casa en su comunidad y los pueblos cercanos desde  hace cinco años para ayudar a su marido con los gastos del hogar y poder cubrir  las necesidades básicas de sus tres hijos.

Ella comenta que le gusta mucho su negocio ya que lo realiza en su tiempo libre y ha logrado buenas amistades. Un préstamo de  VisionFund y de Kiva dará a Paula la oportunidad de ampliar su negocio con la compra de más catálogos, zapatos y ropa interior. Con los ingresos adicionales que obtendrá, Paula será capaz de proporcionar una vida mejor para su familia.

Los demás integrantes del grupo son:
Mireya venta de abarrotes
Silvia venta de bisutería
Alicia venta de frutas y legumbres
texts.en:
Las Periquitas (Flat) is the name of this communal bank of four people.  Each member has a different business activity aimed at improving their families' lifestyles.  The group is located in a small community surrounded by sugar cane fields, with sugar cane cultivation being the main business activity in this area.

Paula sells shoes and underwear by catalogue and on a door-to-door basis in her community and nearby villages.  For five years she has been in business helping her husband cover household expenses and providing the basic needs for their three children.

She says she enjoys her work because it allows her free time and has provided her with good friendships.  A loan from VisionFund and Kiva will give Paula the opportunity to expand her business by buying more catalogues, shoes and underwear.  Paula's additional income will allow her to give her family a better lifestyle.

The other members of the group are:
Mireya, grocery sales
Silvia, jewelry sales
Alicia, fruit and vegetables sales

loans.use: To buy shoes and underwear.

loans.name: Erick

texts.es: Erick, tiene la edad  de 21 años, está soltero, vive con sus hermanos y padres  que son su mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes y algunas productos que mejoren las condiciones del suelo y así que las plantas puedan aprovechar mejor los nutrientes, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra en trabajos en conservación de suelos y de asistencia para el café, además de comprar algunas plantas de almácigo para hacer resiembras esto con el objetivo de aumentar la densidad de plantas por área, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que a  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Él no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Erick, 21, is single and lives with is parents and siblings who are his main priority.  He plans to use the loan to buy fertilizers and products to improve the soil conditions so his crops can take better advantage of nutrients and fungicides.  He will also hire workers to care for the soil and help with coffee cultivation.  He will buy copperwood plants, too, to increase plant density in the area which will enhance coffee production.  With these improvements he hopes to earn more profit and improve his family's living conditions.  He also wants to invest a little more in crop cultivation and meet other goals.

This is his first loan through FUDECOSUR.  He has never had any state bank loans and FUDECOSUR is giving him better terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: with his coffee crop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies to help her coffee crops.

loans.name: Humberto

texts.es: Humberto, tiene la edad  de 70 años, está casado, vive con su esposa  que es su mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes y algunas productos que mejoren las condiciones del suelo, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra en trabajos de asistencia para el café, además de comprar algunas plantas de almácigo para hacer resiembras esto con el objetivo de aumentar la densidad de plantas por área y así tener en los próximos años una mejor cosecha, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que ha  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Él no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Humberto, 70, is married and lives with his wife, who is his first priority. With this loan he is planning to buy fertilizers, some products to improve the soil’s condition and fungicides, and to pay for the labor needed in his coffee plantations. He will also buy some coffee plants to replant with the objective of increasing the density and have a better production during the coming years. He wants to make good use of the soil’s fertility and the weather conditions favoring the crop.

With these improvements he hopes to make better profits and improve his family’s living conditions. He also hopes to be able to invest a little in his plantations and achieve some of his goals. This is the first loan he receives from FUDECOSUR. He had not received loans from state-owned banks before, but FUDECOSUR granted him a loan more easily and with a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his coffee plantations and pay for labor.

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.es: Jose, tiene 41 años de edad, vive en unión libre con su esposa con quien tiene dos hijos, vive en el municipio Minas de Oro, Yoro. Toda su vida ha sido agricultor de granos básicos. lleva 15 años de cultivar una parcela de café de donde saca sus ingresos necesarios. Para poder darle mantenimiento y mejorar su cosecha ha decidido solicitar un préstamo por 20,000 lempiras con el cual va comprar fertilizantes y abonos para asistir a la finca de café. Su objetivo es ser gran productor, para darle calidad de vida a su familia y mantener bien su finca.
texts.en:
Jose is 41 years old and lives in a common-law marriage. He has two children and lives in the municipality of Minas de Oro, Yoro. He has worked all his life growing grains. For fifteen years, he has worked in a coffee plot, making a living out of it.

In order to give maintenance to his crops, he decided to request a loan of 20,000 lempiras [NHL] to buy fertilizers and compost for his coffee plantations. His goal is to become a large producer, so that he can give his family a good quality of life and be able to keep his property in good condition.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and compost for his coffee plantations.

loans.name: Hellen Patricia

texts.es: Hellen Patricia, tiene la edad  de 34 años, está casada, vive con su esposo y sus hijos  que son su mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes para aplicarle antes de la maduración y así la cosecha se desarrolle bien y tenga un buen rendimiento y algunas productos que mejoren las condiciones del suelo, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra en trabajos de asistencia para el café, además de comprar algunas plantas de almácigo para hacer resiembras esto con el objetivo de aumentar la densidad de plantas por área y así tener en los próximos años una mejor cosecha, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que ha  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Ella no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Hellen Patricia is 34 years old and is married. She lives with her husband and their children who are her main priority. With her loan she intends to buy fertilizers to apply during the [coffee] growing season so that the crop will develop well and she will have a good yield. She will also buy products to improve the condition of the soil and fungicides, and pay for manual labour to help with the work involved in coffee growing. She also wants to buy seedlings so she can replant in order to increase the density of plants by area so that in future years she will have a better harvest, also taking advantage of the good fertility of the soil and climatic and other conditions which are favourable for growing coffee. 

With these improvements to her crop Hellen Patricia hopes to make a bit of profit so she can improve her family's living conditions and also invest a little more in her cultivation and achieve some of her goals.

This is the first loan she has had from FUDECOSUR. She had not had other loans previously from State banks, but FUDECOSUR has offered her the loan with better terms and a much lower rate of interest.

loans.use: to grow coffee.

loans.name: Paulina Del Rocio

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Mujeres Al Progreso, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, es una zona con gran vegetación.
En este lugar vive la señora Paulina, tiene 33 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos niñas de  7  y 2 años de edad, el mayor estudia en escuela. Su esposo es guardia de seguridad.
Doña Paulina para ayudar con los gastos del hogar se dedica al comercio, desde hace 15 años a punta de esfuerzo y trabajo logro surtir una pequeña tienda de víveres en su casa, la misma que con la ayuda de los créditos a podido sacarla adelante, allí vende todo tipo de productos como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, legumbres, verduras y frutas, además de aguas, gaseosas, entre otras cosas, ella pasa todo el día en su pequeño local y solo sale de allí por ratitos para realizar sus tareas en la casa pero si llega algún cliente deja todo ya que sus clientes son lo más importante.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, entre otros víveres que vende en su local. Es fundadora del Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos. 
Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
In the city of Tosagua the communal bank Mujeres Al Progreso [Women for Progress] meets every fortnight. This place is known for being very dynamic, and most of the inhabitants work in agriculture or rearing animals, as there is a lot of vegetation in the area. 33-year-old Paulina lives here. She is married and from this relationship she has 2 daughters aged 7 and 2. The older one goes to primary school. Paulina's husband is a security guard.

In order to help with the household expenses Paulina runs a business. Fifteen years ago through sheer hard work she managed to set up a small provisions shop in her home and with the help of the loans she has been able to move the business forward. In it she sells all sorts of products such as rice, sugar, oil, detergents, fruit and vegetables as well as water, fizzy drinks and other items. She spends all day in her small shop and only leaves for short periods of time to do a few household tasks but if customers arrive she drops everything as her customers are more important. 

Paulina will use the loan to buy more stock for her shop. She will buy rice, sugar, oil and other provisions which she sells in the shop. She is a founder member of the communal bank and she likes it because of the help the loans give them. Her goals are to keep progressing in her business and for her shop to keep on growing.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil and other provisions.

loans.name: Siguitemason Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe SIGUITEMASON, composé exclusivement de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tingolé commune de Binko, préfecture de Dioila, Région de Koulikoro (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Les femmes du groupe SIGUITEMASON sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du riz, les condiments, des tissus et le charbon de bois.
La cliente Djeneba  la personne au milieu des debout, compte acheter une trois pièces de tissu à Bamako avec ce prêt.. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12000 FCFA dont une partie  sera  réutilisée dans l’activité et le reste dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Siguitemason is made up of women who are all married, have an average age of 47 years and an average of 5 children each.  They live in traditional, extended families in the village of Tingolé, town of Binko, Dioila prefecture in the region of Koulikoro ( third largest, administrative region of the Republic of Mali ).  The women are all family, neighbours or friends.  This will be their second group loan and will be used to buy rice, spices and seasonings, fabric and charcoal.  

Djeneba is standing in the middle, at the back of the photo.  She will buy three lengths of fabric in Bamako with this loan.  Djeneba expects to earn an average of 12,000 francs CFA a month, of which, part will be reinvested in her business, and part will be used to meet her family's expenses.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Tawfiq

texts.en: Tawfiq is a 31-year-old married man and father of one child who lives in Taiz, Yemen. He worked hard in a small company to save enough to establish a grocery store. He did this in order to generate enough income to support his household expenses. This business is Tawfiq’s source of income so that he is able to give his family a better quality of life. With the thought of generating more income and being able to offer his customers a greater variety of products, he wants to increase the stock of products that he has. However, he does not have enough capital to be able to buy the products from his providers. He therefore requested a loan of 150,000 YER from AMB that will give him the opportunity to buy food staples in order to stock his store and offer his customers a greater variety. He hopes that with the loan he will be able to increase his sales because he will be offering his customers more products. In the future, Tawfiq dreams of his business growing and being able to set up a supermarket so that his children can enjoy financial stability.

loans.use: to buy food staples in order to stock his store and offer his customers a greater variety of goods.

loans.name: Wilikoumado Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Wilikoumado, composé exclusivement de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tingole commune de Binko, préfecture de Dioila, Région de Koulikoro (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Les femmes du groupe Wilikoumado sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du riz, le haricot le poisson, les céréales et les condiments.
La cliente Rokia la première debout  à gauche, est vendeuse de fruits et légumes. Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter une grande quantité de fruits et légumes (tomates, oranges). Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 24000 FCFA dont une partie  sera  réutilisée dans l’activité et le reste dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The women of the Wilikoumado Group are all married with an average of 3 children and, on average, they are 40 years old.  They live in traditional, extended families in the village of Tingole, town of Binko, Dioila prefecture in the region of Koulikoro ( third largest, administrative region of Mali ).  They are all part of the same family, neighbours or friends.  This will be their first group loan, and will be used to buy rice, beans, fish, cereals, spices and seasoning.  

Rokia is standing at the back, on the left of the picture.  She sells fruit and vegetables.  With this loan she will buy a large quantity of fruit and vegetables ( tomatoes and oranges ).  She expects to earn 24,000 francs CFA which she will reinvest in her business and use to pay the expenses of her family.

loans.use: to buy fruit and vegetables.

loans.name: Kelvis Honorio

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Mujeres Al Progreso, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, es una zona con gran vegetación.
En este lugar vive es señor Kelvis, el tiene 40 años de edad, está casado y fruto de esta relación tiene cinco  hijos de 17, 15, 13, 10 y 8 años, tres de ellos estudian en colegio y los menores en escuela. Su esposa es ama de casa. 
Don Kelvis es chofer de profesión pero también se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo y zapatos para lo cual recorre la ciudad y sitios cercanos ofreciendo sus productos los mismos que deja a créditos y cobra cada 8 días, su mujer también le ayuda vendiendo en su casa si algún cliente necesita de alguna prenda, el lleva más de 15 años dedicado a esta actividad la cual le permite salir adelante y darle el pan diario a sus hijos.
Este crédito es para  comprar zapatos y ropa de todo tipo. Esta desde el inicio en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y de gran ayuda. 
Su sueño es seguir adelante.
texts.en:
In the city of Tosagua the communal bank Mujeres Al Progreso meets every fortnight. This place is known for being very dynamic, and most of the inhabitants work in agriculture or rearing animals, as there is a lot of vegetation in the area. Kelvis lives here. He is 40 years old and is married. He and his wife have 5 children aged 17, 15, 13, 10 and 8 years old. Three of them are at secondary school and the younger ones are at primary school. Kelvis's wife is a housewife. 

Kelvis is a driver by trade but he also works in business, selling all types of clothing and shoes, travelling through the city and local areas with his items for sale. He sells on credit and collects money every week. His wife also helps him selling from home if any customer needs an item of clothing. He has been doing this for 15 years which has enabled him to get on in life and put food on the table for his children. 

This loan is to buy shoes and all types of clothing. Kelvis has been in the communal bank since the beginning and he likes it because the loans are quick and are a great help. His dream is to make progress in life.

loans.use: to buy shoes and clothing.

loans.name: Ángela Valentina

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Mujeres Al Progreso, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, es una zona con gran vegetación.
En este lugar vive la señora Ángela, tiene 20 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen una niña de 3 años. Su esposo es comerciante.
Doña Ángela junto al esposo se dedican a la elaboración y distribución de embutidos, trabajan todos los días, primero elaborando sus productos los mismos que tienen mucha demanda ya que son deliciosos, luego de esto se desplazan por toda la ciudad dejando sus productos en tiendas y restaurantes, lo que más venden es la longaniza que es deliciosa y el deleite de las personas que la prueban razón por lo cual tienen muchos clientes, ellos llevan 4 años con este negocio   que les permite salir adelante con un trabajo honrado.  
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar carne de chancho para preparar sus embutidos. Esta desde el inicio  en el Banco Comunal  y le gusta porque los créditos son de mucha ayuda para ellos. 
Su sueño es tener su casa propia pues viven en casa de familiares.
texts.en:
In the city of Tosagua the communal bank Mujeres Al Progreso [Women for Progress] meets every fortnight. This place is known for being very dynamic, and most of the inhabitants work in agriculture or rearing animals, as there is a lot of vegetation in the area. 20-year-old Angela lives here. She is married and they have a 3-year-old daughter.

Her husband is in business. Together he and Angela earn a living making and selling sausages. They work every day, first making their products which are in great demand since they are delicious. Then they travel around the city delivering their products to shops and restaurants. Their product which sells the most is "longaniza" [type of sausage] which is delicious and delights everyone who tastes it. Because of this they have a lot of customers. They have been doing this work for 4 years and having a decent job has enabled them to make progress in life. 

Angela will use this loan to buy pork for making her sausages. She has been in the communal bank since the beginning and she likes it because the loans are a great help to them. Her dream is to have her own house, as currently they live with family.

loans.use: to buy pork.

loans.name: Aloysius

texts.en:
Aloysius is a man of 50, married to Rose and a father of three children. He is a tailor in Kangemi, and has been in this business for five years. He gets a monthly income of 14,000 shillings.

This will be Aloysius' first loan with KADET LTD; he plans to use the entire loan to buy fabric for making clothes. 

In the future, he wants to educate his children to the university level.

loans.use: to buy fabric for making clothes

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 44 years old; he has one child, who is five. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production; they need fertilizer to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and he is responsible for repaying the loan. All borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. 

Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a 20-year-old young man, married and a father of a three-month-old baby. He is rears livestock in the outskirts of Narok town, kenya, and has been in livestock farming for the past year. The livestock trade earns a monthly income of about KES 9,000. 

Julius learned about Kadet from one of the livestock traders in town who are financed by Kadet. He is getting his first loan of KES 15,000 from Kadet; he plans to purchase more livestock for fattening and resale.

He hopes to purchase a motorcycle from the business proceeds to maximize his income. 

His goal is to attain financial stability, and bring up a healthy and wealthy family.

loans.use: to purchase livestock to sell

loans.name: Msakuzi A2 Group

texts.en:
Calista, a member of Msakuzi A2 group, has been running a pharmacy business for 11 years now. Calista is in her mid 40s, a married woman with two children who are in school. She works from 8am to 11pm each working day, and is able to make a very good return each month. 

This will be her fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to open another pharmacy, and restocked more medicine. Calista managed to pay back all her previous loans successfully. With the profit she earned from the business, she bought a plot of land, covered home expenses, and school fees. 

She will use this loan to replenish medicines in her pharmacy. 

Calista dreams that one day she will be able to build a house for her family. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "MSAKUZI A2", which totals three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish more medicines for her pharmacy.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma, composé exclusivement de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Dibida, commune de kalake, préfecture de Baroueli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de condiment de tubercules de la farine et des céréales. 
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire. 
La cliente Bintou la personne assise à droite, est vendeuse de friture de farine de blé. Elle compte acheter 1 sac de farine et un demi-sac de sucre. Son cycle d’achat vente est d’une semaine. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10000 FCFA dont une partie  sera  réutilisé dans l’activité et l’autre épargnée en vu d’acheter une chèvre.
texts.en:
The women of the Sabougnouma Group are all married with 4 children, and an average age of 43 years.  They live in traditional, extended families in the village of Dibida, Kalake town, Baroueli prefecture in the region of Ségou ( fourth largest, administrative region of the Republic of Mali ).  They are all part of the same family, neighbours or friends.  They buy and sell spices and seasoning, tubers, flour and cereals.  This will be the tenth group loan for the Sabougnouma women.  

Bintou is sitting on the right, at the front of the picture.  She sells wheatflour fritters.  She will buy 1 sack of flour and half a sack of sugar with this loan.  Her purchase-to-sale cycle is one week.  She expects to earn 10,000 francs CFA a month and will reinvest part of it in her business, and save the rest in order to buy a goat.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Erik

texts.en:
Erik was born and lives in the town of Kapan in the Syuniq region. He is married and has a nice family: a wife and an 8-year-old daughter. Erik's wife doesn't work as she has too much work about the house to take care of. So Erik is the only breadwinner of the family. 

Erik has been involved in the construction business for many years. After years of tireless hard work, Erik now is a very skilled constructor. He is providing renovation services to locals in the Kapan region and is earning an income for his family.

Now there is a big demand for internal decoration of houses and Erik's job is much in demand. But, to be able to work more effectively, Erik needs financial support to purchase tools and materials. He has been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. 
So this loan is very important for Erik to be able to implement the construction process and provide more income for his beloved family.

loans.use: to pay for tools and materials to implement the construction process

loans.name: Inobat

texts.ru: Иноят замужняя женщина имеет 4 детей. Она занимается куплей продажей скота. В сезонное время перепродаёт рис.  Её дом находиться недалеко от рисового поля. Каждый год она с сентября по ноябрь работает на рисовом поле с сыном и мужем выращивают рис и по сезону продают.   Когда заканчивается сезон риса она до весны начинает реализацию скота. Также ее муж работает охранником в колхозе,так как сезонная работа не имеет постоянный доход. Иноят со своей семьей планируют приобрести машину для перевозки скота, так как они находятся далеко от города, и им трудно добираться до центра и развозить скот или урожай.  Они очень надеются на поддержку от Арванд, Иноят и ее семья будут очень благодарны на осуществления их планов.
texts.en: Inoyat is married and has four children. She sells livestock. She also seasonally sells rice. Her house is located near a rice field. Each year from September to November she works in the rice field with her son and husband to grow and then sell the rice. When the rice season ends she she is engaged in selling livestock until the spring. Her husband also works as a security guard at a collective farm, for seasonal work does not provide a continuous income. Inoyat and her family are planning to buy a vehicle to transport livestock, because they live far away from the city and it is difficult for them reach downtown and deliver livestock or rice. Inoyat and her family are placing her hopes on assistance from Arvand, and they will be very grateful if they can realize their plans.

loans.use: to buy a car for delivering livestock and rice

loans.name: Nuriniso

texts.ru: Нуринисо 48 лет. Она замужем и на воспитании имеет 3 детей. Нуринисо имеет высшее педагогическое образование. Она более 25 лет работает в средней школе учительницей географии. Нуриннисо и ее муж стараются, чтобы их дети получили высшее образование. Ее муж электрик. Нуринисо помогла своему сыну поступить в университет. Данное время ее сын является студентом Худжандского Государственного Университета. Он учится в заочное отделение. Нуринисо должна оплатить за учебный договор своего ребенка, но не имеет денег. Она запрашивает займ для оплаты учебного договора. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Nuriniso is 48, married, and has 3 children. She has a college teaching degree. For more than 25 years she has been teaching geography at the high school. Nuriniso and her husband are trying to make sure that their children receive a college education. Her husband is an electrician. Nuriniso helped her son get into the university. Right now he is a student at the Khujand State University, where he is in the distance education department.  Nuriniso has to pay his tuition, but cannot afford it.She is asking for a loan to pay for the tuition, and awaits your kind assistance.

loans.use: To pay for her son's college tution

loans.name: Apollo

texts.en: Apollo, a married man, plans to buy baby bulls that he will raise for a period of 6 months and later sell at a profit. He says that UGAFODE through the quarterly loan payment system has made his business flourish because he has been able to buy the bulls at a cheaper price, feed them consistently, and sell them after they have fattened. His status of life and his household has considerably improved.He hope to keep getting the loans until his business becomes sustainable.

loans.use: To buy baby bulls to raise and sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a single man of twenty-eight years. He supports his mother. He does pig, mushroom, and crop farming in Nderi in the outskirts of Kangemi. He has been in this business for four years and gets a monthly income of five thousand Kenyan shillings.

This will be Stephen's third loan with KADET LTD.  He plans to use the entire loan to plant mushrooms. In the future he wants to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy material to grow mushrooms

loans.name: Akhtari Group

texts.en:
Akhtari is 36 years old and lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan with her three children. She is part of a 3 member group and requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan. 

She wants the financing to invest in a wholesale business as part of her husband’s wholesale company. As this company is the only source of income for their family, she wants to expand it through this financing and make her life happy. 

She is very experienced and professional in her dealings and has been operating her business for the past three years. Akhtari is hopeful that the loan will be a successful one for them and bring positive changes in the life of their family.

loans.use: to pay for expansion of her wholesale business.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es: Doña Gregoria, tiene 52 años de edad, está casada y reside en el municipio de Morazán, Yoro junto a su esposo y sus tres nietos. Hace varios años que se dedica a la venta de plásticos como ser tambos, barriles de plástico, vasos, platos,etc. De manera ambulante. El prestamo que solicito es por 10,000 Lempiras y lo va invertir en la compra de más plásticos como tambos,cubetas,platos,vasos y barriles, y asi poder tener más surtido el negocio. Su meta es mantener siempre el negocio y apoyar a sus nietos con la educación.
texts.en:
52-year-old Gregoria is married and lives in the town of Morazán, Yoro, with her husband and their 3 grandchildren. For several years she has earned a living as a street vendor, selling plastic items such as containers, plastic barrels, glasses, plates etc. 

Gregoria is asking for a loan of 10,000 Lempiras to buy more plastic items such as containers, bowls, plates, glasses and barrels, so she can stock her business better. 

Her goal is to always keep the business going and to help her grandchildren with their education.

loans.use: to buy plastic items such as containers, barrels, bowls, buckets and plates to sell.

loans.name: Naisiae

texts.en:
Naisiae is 48 years old and married to Taki.  She is the mother of five children. She has been selling fruits and vegetables in the Narok market for the last four years.  She earns a monthly income of 10,000 KES.

She learned about KADET from some other women in the market who were already being financed by KADET.

She has been advanced a fourth loan of 20,000 KES after successfully paying off the previous ones.  This loan will enable her to acquire more vegetables for resale and expand her stall. The proceeds will be used to pay school fees for her children and to diversify to include the sale of cereals.

Her hope is to provide her children with higher levels of learning.

loans.use: to expand her market stall

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Married to Alexander, Tabitha is a 47-year-old mother of five children. She plants and sells vegetables and also does dairy farming. In business for 11 years, she earns a monthly income of 43,000 shillings.

This will be Tabitha's second loan with KADET LTD, with which she plans to buy a dairy cow. In the future, she wants to educate her children to university level.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, a 20-year-old man married man with no children, is from the Migori region of Kenya. He supports two people in his family.

The operator of an electronic shop for five years, John is requesting a loan with KADET LTD to increase his stock. He will use the anticipated profit to purchase land. 

John's dream is to have a better life.

loans.use: to increase his store stock

loans.name: Aloysie

texts.en:
Eloysie is 59 years old. She will use the Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase her production. With the profits from her farming she wishes to invest in her business.  In the future she hopes she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith lives in a small town in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, near Tanzania. Inconsistent rains, especially recently, have made farming difficult, and the poverty rates in the county are above the Kenyan average. 

Beekeeping is somewhat new to Kwale, but the passion fruit farms and mangrove forests throughout the area provide excellent sources of nectar for bee colonies. Many farmers in the area have expressed excitement at the prospect of owning their own hives and having a second source of income from their honey to help care for their families.  

Faith is single, and has been farming for four years. She is currently growing bananas on her land, as well as some other small crops. She wanted to work with Honey Care because their hive technicians do all of the technical work, while she can gather revenue from her hives. 

This is Faith’s first loan with Kiva, and she plans to use the income generated by her beehives to pay her university fees.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is 39 years old. He has spent fifteen years in maize farming. He will use Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production: there is a need to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. As the cooperative's leader, Jean Pierre is responsible for repaying the loan.


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production

loans.name: Emelite

texts.en:
Emelite is 47 years old. She is single-handedly taking care of seven children. She will use the Kiva loan to pay for labor costs and fertilizer during maize production; she needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase her production. With profits from her farming she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. As the cooperative's leader, Emelite is responsible for repaying the loan

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs and fertilizer.

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en:
Saidi is 44 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have six children. He will use his Kiva loan to pay labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business. In the future he would like to acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay labor costs and purchase fertilizer during maize production

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is married and has seven children. 

He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production.

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en:
Khodor is a 29-year-old single man who has been working as a carpenter since 15 years ago. He was only 14 years old when he left school and started to work in order to help his parents in their living. He is a hard worker and very talented in his domain due to his long experience. Khodor is highly recommended by his customers because of the good quality of work he provides.

He is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to pay for his wedding expenses and buy necessary home appliances. 
 
He hopes to be capable of expanding his working place and increasing his income in the future to make sure that he can reply easily to his future beloved family's needs.

loans.use: to pay for his wedding expenses and buy necessary home appliances.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 27-year-old single man who has worked as a barber for 12 years.  He is his family’s sole breadwinner.  He is responsible for the living expenses of three members of his family. For this reason, he works hard and puts substantial effort into continuing to improve his business. 

In April 2012, he opened his current shop and is working hard to develop it. Because his income is low compared to his high expenses, Hussein can’t save enough cash to improve and develop his business. For this reason, he is acquiring a youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase his business capital with special gels, beauty supplies and necessary tools for developing his business.

He hopes that, through this loan, he will be able to increase his income which will help him to expand his workplace.

loans.use: to increase his business capital with special gels, beauty supplies and necessary tools for developing his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy ten bags of potatoes

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is from Iraq. He is 34 years old, married and has two children. Ali is the sole provider of the family.

Ali owns a small grocery store where he sells the basic supplies of a house like canned food, dairy products, snacks, drinks and detergents. He has been practicing this business since 2004 and through practice he has gained good experience. Ali is well-known in the neighborhood and has an excellent reputation thanks to his good products.

Ali is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD. He will use this loan to install a new rolling shutter for his grocery store as well as to buy more goods to sell. Ali is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so that he may provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to install a new rolling shutter for his grocery store as well as to buy more goods to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 50-year-old from Suna Migori which is located in the Western part of Kenya. She supports seven people in her family and is married to Mr. Alex. She has five children who are 17, 15, 14, 13 and 10 years old respectively.

She has a small-scale retail shop where she sells plastics. She has been doing this business for the last three years and gets a monthly income of KES 40,000. She has requested her fifth loan with KADET Ltd, which she will use to to increase her working capital. She will use the anticipated profit to expand the business.

Her dream is to expand the business so as to earn more income that will support her family and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of plastic goods.

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en:
Jeremiah lives outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for its rain forest. Many farmers in the area grow maize, sugar cane and bananas, with maize being the primary crop. The density of the old growth trees in the Kakamega forest, and the variety of crops grown in the area, make this an excellent area for beekeeping. 

Jeremiah is married, and has six children. His wife runs a small business, while Jeremiah is involved with projects on their land. He has been farming for forty-seven years, and is currently growing bananas and vegetables, raising cattle, and keeping beehives of his own. Jeremiah is excited to get more hives, as he says "I love honey, the income I will make from it, [and] I need the bees to help me in pollinating my crops."

This is Jeremiah's first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to pay his children's school fees and expand the number of projects on his land. In the future, Jeremiah's dream is to expand his land, start more projects, and eventually construct rental houses.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean De Dieu, aged 33, is married with three children. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production: there is a  need to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. As the cooperative's leader, Jean de Dieu is responsible for repaying the loan.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production

loans.name: Gabriella Group

texts.en:
Gabriella is the featured borrower of Gabriella’s group. She joined with her group members to acquire a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua because they have been friends since they arrived to work in Lebanon to improve their beloved families' lives.

Gabriella is a 50-year-old married mother of two children. Gabriella sells clothes, Brazilian gold, and silver to help her husband in making their living and covering their children's needs. She is a hard worker who puts much effort into expanding her trade and increasing her income. She is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise through buying newly released bags, clothes, silver accessories, and Brazilian gold, which will help in diversifying her products to attract customers’ attention. Gabriella is at the center of the picture wearing a black and white top.
As of the other group members, Ma Gema is the first one standing on the left side of the picture, while Eufemia is the first one on the right.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise through buying new released bags, clothes, silver accessories, and Brazilian gold, which will help in diversifying her products to attract customers’ attention

loans.name: Theoneste

texts.en:
Theoneste is 38 years old. He has five children aged between one and ten. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. There is a need to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. As the cooperative's leader, Theoneste is responsible for repaying the loan.

Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and buy fertilizers.

Edissa is 49 years old. She is married with seven children. She will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase her production. With profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To support labor costs and purchase fertilizer for maize production.

loans.name: Valens

texts.en:
Valens is 39 years old. He has five children aged between 4 and 12. He will use Kiva loan to support labor costs and pay for fertilizer for maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and pay for fertilizer for maize production.

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is a 25-year-old young man from a place called Oruba town in Migori county, which is located in the western part of Kenya. He supports four people in his family and is married to Metrine, who is also a business lady. They have two children who are 5 and 16 months old respectively.

He has an electronics shop that has been in an operation for the last six years and gets a monthly income of 10,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). He is requesting a loan with KADET LTD, which he will use to add more stock. He will use the anticipated profit to educate his children and invest in another business.

His dream is to expand the business to a wholesale one as well as educating his children.

loans.use: To add stock of electronic appliances.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 39 years old, male and married. He has two children, 17 and 11 years respectively, whom he supports. Peter runs a cereal business shop which  has lasted for four years now and is located at Marereni. He earns a monthly income of 87,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a KADET officer, and he is taking a third loan from KADET of 20,000 KES. He intends to use it to buy more stock of maize, beans, cow peas and green grams (mung beans). 

His previous loan of 10,000 KES was paid back successfully. Peter will use the anticipated profit to expand his business by making it to be a cereal depot. His hopes and dreams for his future are to expand his business and also make sure his children get a better education and have brighter futures.

loans.use: To add stock of maize, beans, cow peas and green grams (mung beans) to sell to his buyers.

loans.name: Thadee

texts.en:
Thadee is 47 years old. He is married with three children, and has been farming rice for the past 20 years. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and fertilizer during rice production. Fertilizer is needed in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. As the cooperative's leader, Thadee is responsible for repaying the loan.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To support labor costs and fertilizer during rice production.

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar lives in Likoni, Kenya. He is a husband and father of four children. Three of the children attend school. He runs a workshop that deals in metal work and steel fabrications. He has been doing this for the last one year, and the business has been improving steadily. 

He knew of Milango through friends and now he seeks a loan to buy tools and materials for the business. He hopes that in five years' time, the business will grow into a reputable showroom. The challenges that he faces in the business include price changes and inflation. He will use the income he will raise to expand his operations.

loans.use: to buy tools and materials.

loans.name: María Dolores

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Mujeres Al Progreso, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, es una zona con gran vegetación.
En este lugar vive la señorita María, tiene 23  años de edad, está soltera y vive en casa de sus padres. Lleva cuatro ciclos  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias a los créditos ella puede financiar su negocio el cual le permite generar sus propios ingresos para el bien propio y de su familia. 
Doña María es una jovencita muy trabajadora que le gusta ganar sus propios ingresos para ella y para ayudar a sus padres que son de escasos recursos económicos, ella se dedica a la venta de productos de Avon y Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su  forma de venta es recorriendo por su localidad, cuando está desocupada ella visita a sus clientes ya sea para vender o para cobrar ya que deja a crédito y cobra cada 8 días. Tiene 4  años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien, lo que más vende son los perfumes ya que son muy buenos.
Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y bisutería. 
Su sueño es tener una boutique.
texts.en:
Every 2 weeks, the Communal Bank ‘Mujeres al Progreso’ (Women to the Progress) meets in the city of Tosagua, a place of beautiful vegetation, known for its dynamism and because its residents work in agriculture and animal husbandry. María lives in this place. She is 23 years old, single and lives with her parents. 

She has been through 4 cycles with the Communal Bank, and she enjoys it because through the loans she can finance her business, which allows her to generate her own income for her well-being and that of her family. María is a very hardworking woman, who is proud to earn her own salary to support herself, and to help her parents, who have limited economic resources. 

María sells beauty products from Avon and Yanbal (make up, perfumes and women’s accessories). She sells cosmetics by walking throughout the city; she visits her clients to either sell new products or to collect payments -which she does every 8 days- 

María has been selling cosmetics for 4 years now, and it is going quite well. The perfumes are what she sells the most, because of their good quality.
Maria will use this loan to buy perfumes, lotions, make-up, and costume jewelry.  Her dream is to own her own boutique.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, lotions, make-up, and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 41 years old. He is married and has been in the rice farming business for the past 20 years. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and pay for fertilizer for rice production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and pay for fertilizer for rice production.

loans.name: Humaira

texts.en:
Humaira, resident of Rawalpindi (Pakistan), is a 45-year-old lady. She has a family consisting of her spouse and one son. Humaira’s husband is running a transport business in the area which is the only source of income for the family. 

The professional approach coupled with her husband's four year’s of experience running the business, gives confidence to the family to expand the business further. They are convinced that the business has potential for growth but are constrained due to lack of finances.  

Humaira has requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan in order to purchase a vehicle for her husband’s business. She is confident that the availability of the requested loan will greatly contribute towards a considerable increase in their monthly income.

loans.use: to buy a vehicle.

loans.name: Hashim

texts.en:
Hashim is 25 years old. He is single and lives in Hodeida, Yemen. 

He is employed in a the Ministry of Interior and gets a low salary that is not enough to cover his needs. 

He is requesting a loan of 67,000 YER from AMB to help him cover the costs of purchasing a new laptop. This will help him to enhance his skills in using the computer and to finish his work reports on time, which will ensure better conditions for him at work and improve his income.

loans.use: to help him cover the costs of purchasing a new laptop.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 48 years old and supports two of her grandchildren who are at school. She buys tomatoes from farmers and sells them in the Narok market. Alice has been in this business for the last fifteen years making a monthly income of about KES 9,000. She learnt about Kadet from some other women in the market which are already being financed by Kadet Ltd.

Alice has advanced with her first loan of KES 30,000 which will facilitate her in the purchase of tomatoes from farmers and transporting them to the market. She will use the proceeds to cater for the family's basic needs and repay the loan.

Her hope is to open another grocery stall in the quest to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is twenty-four years old and supports his siblings who are at school. He has operated a motorcycle transport business for the last three years in Narok town. He earns approximately KES 15,000 in a month.

Eric has been issued with a second loan after successfully paying off the first one, of KES 30,000. He will use the funds to repair his motorcycle as well as replace the worn-out parts. Eric plans to refurblish his house with the proceeds from the busines.

Eric's dream is to succeed in life.

loans.use: to reapair his broken motorcycle.

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip is 35 years old and married to Metrine. They both support a family of five. He runs a car-washing business in Kapsabet town in Nandi County, which is served by KADET Ltd. This has been his income-generating business for the last six years; he gets an average monthly profit of 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). 

He has borrowed a loan of 70,000 KES, this being his fourth loan after paying the previous loan successfully. He plans to use 40,000 KES to purchase a new washing machine to supplement what he currently uses. He will use the profits from the business to pay his children’s school fees and expand his business.

His dream and hope is to expand his business and enhance new technologies in his business.

loans.use: To purchase a car-washing machine.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is 21 years old. He is married and has one child. He will use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. They need to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production.

loans.name: Victoire

texts.en:
Victoire is aged 35. He is a father of four children and has been practicing rice farming for the past 10 years. He will use the Kiva loan to pay for labor costs and fertilizer during rice production. Fertilizer is needed in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

This loan is part of Urwego Opportunity Bank's program targeting farmers who are members of cooperatives. The loan goes to the cooperative's leader (pictured) on the group's behalf, and all borrowers benefiting from this loan receive financing such as quality seeds from the Rwandan government. The loan is also covered by insurance in case of crop failure. As the cooperative's leader, Victoire is responsible for repaying the loan

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs and fertilizer.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 30-year-old woman who lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, with her spouse and four children. 

She requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan for the amount of 15,000 PKR. She wants the financing to invest in buying a mobile accessories shop  where she can sell cell phone batteries, chargers, casings, head phones, cell phone bags, etc. 

Her husband has a cell phone accessories shop. As this shop is the only source of income for their family, she wants to expand it by buying a new shop in the market through this financing and make her life happy.
 
She is very experienced and professional in her dealings and has been operating her business for the past four years. Nasreen is hopeful that the loan will be a productive one for them and bring positive changes in the life of her family.

loans.use: to buy a cell phone accessories shop.

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer is a lady of 33 years, married and a mother of three children. 

She sells clothes in Limuru and has been in this business for five years now. She gets a monthly income of 12,500 shillings.

This will be Jeniffer's first loan with KADET Ltd. She plans to use the entire loan to buy clothes for resale. She wants to open a boutique and educate her children in future.

loans.use: to buy clothes for selling.

loans.name: Carmen Patricia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Mujeres Al Progreso, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, es una zona con gran vegetación.
En este lugar vive la señora Carmen, tiene 41 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y de esta relación tiene cuatro hijos de 24, 23, 20 y 18 años, dos aun viven en su casa y el menor estudia en colegio. Su esposo es comerciante.
Doña Carmen es una gran esposa que siempre trata de ayudar a su marido ya sea con los créditos o con sus recursos que a ella le quedan con su negocio, ella se dedica a la venta de productos naturales y productos de Avon (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas), ella tiene una gran cantidad de clientes que siempre le compran y que ha ido consiguiendo con el pasar de los años, mientras ella vende estos productos su marido también recorre la ciudad vendiendo deliciosos granizados y refrescos que son muy degustados por sus clientes. Con estos trabajos han podido sacar adelante a sus hijos ya son más de 15 años que ambos se dedican a estas actividades.
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar productos naturales, cosméticos de Avon, frutas y azúcar para los granizados. Esta desde el inicio  en el Banco Comunal  y le gusta porque el grupo es muy unido. 
Su sueños es seguir adelante.
texts.en:
Every 2 weeks, the Communal Bank ‘Mujeres al Progreso’ (Women to the Progress) meets in the city of Tosagua, a place of beautiful vegetation, known for its dynamism and because its residents work in agriculture and animal husbandry.
